customer_name: Kay Rosaire and Clayton Rosaire Mowrey

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There are multiple animals in need of veterinary care.
• A geriatric brown bear has red, swollen eyelids. The animal was not in the public viewing area. There is excessive,
watery moisture, as well as thick, yellow-green discharge in the inner corner of both eyes. There is hair loss, swelling, and
red skin around the eyes. The licensee noticed this but has not contacted their veterinarian about this issue or taken steps
to treat the condition. Failure to treat abnormal conditions of the eye can prolong pain and discomfort.
• A juvenile male white lion has thickened and abnormally positioned (outwardly rotated) front limbs, particularly the left
wrist. He is dragging his front feet when he walks. The licensee stated these symptoms had been present since the
animal was acquired several months ago. The animal has not received any treatments for this issue. The licensee stated
they had not contacted their vet. Limb abnormalities and associated conditions of young, growing lions can cause long-
term pain and mobility issues if not evaluated and treated to the full extent.
• Three adult goats had moderate to severely overgrown hooves. One geriatric female goat had very overgrown dewclaws
that curled upwards. Overgrown hooves can lead to abnormal gait, and consequently chronic pain.
Each exhibitor shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that includes appropriate methods to prevent, control,
diagnose, and treat diseases.
To be corrected by: May 8, 2025.

Several surfaces in in an outdoor enclosure housing three adult capuchins need maintenance. The wooden walking,
eating and resting platforms are rotted, discolored, and deteriorating. The wood on the floor of their shelter is flaking off
with rough edges.
Rotting and rough edges of wood surfaces prevent effecting cleaning and sanitizing and can affect the health and welfare
of the animal.
All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities – including houses, dens, and other
furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility – that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when
worn or soiled.
To be corrected by: May 23, 2025.

There are multiple areas of housing that are in need of maintenance:
• An indoor feeding area for one adult lion has several areas of rusted ceiling and a rusted gate.
• Two indoor enclosures for an adult liger and an adult tiger have jagged, rusted holes in the sides of the facility walls.
• An outdoor enclosure for an adult tiger, and the gate of a door housing one adult liger has excessive rust, which has led
to the deterioration of the bottom of multiple support poles.
• A wooden shelter in an outdoor enclosure of an adult coatimundi contains several areas of rotten and chewed wood,
including the four wood beams supporting the enclosure.
Facilities must be kept in good repair for the safety and welfare of the animals enclosed therein. The indoor and outdoor
housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and
to contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Charles Palmer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There are multiple animals in need of veterinary care.  
• A geriatric brown bear has red, swollen eyelids. The animal was not in the public viewing area. There is excessive, 
watery moisture, as well as thick, yellow-green discharge in the inner corner of both eyes. There is hair loss, swelling, and

• A juvenile male white lion has thickened and abnormally positioned (outwardly rotated) front limbs, particularly the left 
wrist. He is dragging his front feet when he walks. The licensee stated these symptoms had been present since the 
animal was acquired several months ago. The animal has not received any treatments for this issue. The licensee stated 
they had not contacted their vet. Limb abnormalities and associated conditions of young, growing lions can cause long-

• Three adult goats had moderate to severely overgrown hooves. One geriatric female goat had very overgrown dewclaws 
that curled upwards. Overgrown hooves can lead to abnormal gait, and consequently chronic pain. 
 
Each exhibitor shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that includes appropriate methods to prevent, control, 
diagnose, and treat diseases. 
 
To be corrected by: May 8, 2025. 
3.75(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Several surfaces in in an outdoor enclosure housing three adult capuchins need maintenance. The wooden walking, 
eating and resting platforms are rotted, discolored, and deteriorating. The wood on the floor of their shelter is flaking off 
with rough edges.  
 
Rotting and rough edges of wood surfaces prevent effecting cleaning and sanitizing and can affect the health and welfare 
of the animal.  
 
All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities – including houses, dens, and other

furniture-type fixtures and objects within the facility – that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when 
worn or soiled.  
 
To be corrected by: May 23, 2025. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
There are multiple areas of housing that are in need of maintenance: 
• An indoor feeding area for one adult lion has several areas of rusted ceiling and a rusted gate.  
• Two indoor enclosures for an adult liger and an adult tiger have jagged, rusted holes in the sides of the facility walls. 
• An outdoor enclosure for an adult tiger, and the gate of a door housing one adult liger has excessive rust, which has led 
to the deterioration of the bottom of multiple support poles.  
• A wooden shelter in an outdoor enclosure of an adult coatimundi contains several areas of rotten and chewed wood, 
including the four wood beams supporting the enclosure.  
 
Facilities must be kept in good repair for the safety and welfare of the animals enclosed therein. The indoor and outdoor 
housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and 
to contain the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Charles Palmer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
